intro: Acacia xerophila var. xerophila, commonly known as the desert wattle, is a shrub native to arid regions of Australia. It is characterized by its slender, wiry stems and small, phyllode-like leaves that reduce water loss. The plant produces yellow flowers in spikes, which attract nectar-feeding birds and insects. It is well adapted to dry conditions, with deep root systems and a slow growth rate. This variety is notable for its ecological role in stabilizing soils in harsh environments.

This variant of the species is found in the southern regions of the state, particularly in the coastal and sandy areas. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, adapting well to the harsh conditions of the region. The plant is commonly seen in heathlands and open woodlands. Its distribution is closely linked to the unique climatic and soil conditions of Western Australia.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acacia xerophila var. xerophila was mainly introduced to areas with arid or semi-arid climates, where it thrives in well-drained soils. It is commonly found in regions with low rainfall and high temperatures, making it suitable for restoration projects in degraded landscapes. This plant has been introduced to several parts of Australia, particularly in the inland regions of Queensland and New South Wales. Its ability to fix nitrogen makes it valuable for soil stabilization and improving soil fertility. However, its rapid growth and spread can sometimes lead to competition with native species.
